contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} '''Karyogamy''' is the [[cell fusion|fusion]] of [[pronuclei]] of two [[cell (biology)|cell]]s, as part of [[syngamy]], [[fertilization]], or true [[bacterial conjugation]]. It is one of the two major modes of [[reproduction]] in [[fungi]]. In fungi that lack [[sexual cycle]]s, it is an important source of [[genetic variation]] through the formation of [[somatic diploid]]s. The term comes for the [[Greek (language)|Greek]] ''karuo-'' (from ''karuon'') meaning ''nut'' and ''-gamos'' meaning ''marriage''. [[Category:Reproduction]]It is mainly found in fungal phylum ascomycetes. {{Cell-biology-stub}}
